The "Civil Rights History Project Act of 2009" recognizes the importance of individuals standing up for their rights and beliefs, as demonstrated by the Civil Rights movement. The Act aims to preserve the first-hand memories and stories of those who participated in the movement, including lesser-known individuals who made significant contributions. The Civil Rights movement participants hold valuable first-hand memories that should be recorded for future generations to learn from. A Federal project should collect oral histories to highlight the efforts made by various entities in preserving Civil Rights history. The Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution are suitable repositories for this endeavor. The purpose of this Act is to create a federally sponsored project to collect video and audio recordings of personal histories of individuals involved in the Civil Rights movement. The Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution will preserve and make these oral histories available to the public. This project aims to complement existing documentary work and encourage local efforts to preserve the memories of Civil Rights activists for future generations to appreciate. The Act establishes a joint project at the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture to collect video and audio recordings of participants in the American Civil Rights movement. The project aims to preserve the memories of individuals involved in the movement for future generations to appreciate. The Secretary will establish an oral history project to collect audio and video recordings of Civil Rights movement participants, along with personal histories and relevant materials. The project aims to create a collection, catalog it appropriately, and make it available for public use. The Secretary will establish an oral history project to collect recordings and materials related to the Civil Rights movement. The collection will be cataloged and made available to the public through the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture. The Director of the National Museum of African American History and Culture will oversee the project, and partnerships with other entities may be utilized for its implementation. The Librarian and the Secretary may procure services, accept volunteer help, and make advance payments to collect video and audio recordings for the oral history project on the Civil Rights movement. The Librarian and the Secretary are encouraged to collect donations to support activities related to the Civil Rights movement. Funds provided will be dedicated to the Library of Congress. Private support for Civil Rights History Project is encouraged through donations to the Librarian of Congress. Donated funds will be deposited into a dedicated account and used solely to support activities related to the project.
